name: Circle House
subtitle: World's first Design for Disassembly social housing - 90% of materials recoverable for future reuse
data_source: GXN/3XN Building a Circular Future + Circle House Lab documentation

executive_summary.headline: Europe's first DfD social housing: 60 units designed for 90% material recovery at end of life
key_achievements: 90% of materials designed for disassembly and reuse (target)
35% CO2 reduction over 100-year lifecycle vs traditional build-demolish-rebuild
World's first full-scale Design for Disassembly social housing
Only 6 standardized precast concrete element types
RFID chips in all concrete elements creating digital Material IDs (material passports)
Mechanical fastening throughout - screws/brackets replace glue/sealant
Lime mortar for brick facades (enables future brick recovery)
All installations in accessible shafts (no chasing into walls)
executive_summary.why_flagship: Circle House is paradigm-shifting - rather than using current waste, it designs for future waste elimination. The project proves DfD is viable within Denmark's strict social housing cost framework. Material passports and disassembly instructions ensure future contractors can recover 90% of materials regardless of who owns the building.
executive_summary.why_tier: Completeness score 85/100 (Grade A). Comprehensive GXN/Circle House Lab documentation including disassembly manual, material passport methodology, and DfD specifications.

materials.description: Precast concrete structure using only 6 standardized element types - walls, beams, floor slabs
design_features: Mechanical bolted connections replace cast-in-place joints
Elements can be lifted out individually for reuse
Standardization ensures compatibility with future buildings

materials.description: RFID chips embedded in all concrete elements creating digital Material IDs
All facades use reversible mechanical connections - screws and brackets replace glue and sealant
Lime mortar used instead of cement mortar - weaker bond allows bricks to be cleaned and reused
materials.design_feature: Lime mortar enables future brick recovery without damage

materials.description: Floating/click-lock floors instead of glued - can be taken up intact
materials.design_feature: Floors laid loose or clicked together for easy removal

materials.description: All installations in accessible shafts or behind demountable panels - no chasing into walls
materials.design_feature: Services routed through visible/accessible pathways for future modification

circularity.scope: Materials recoverable for reuse at end of life
circularity.verification: Design target - to be verified at disassembly

co2_reduction.mechanism: Materials reused rather than demolished at end of first life

lca_scope.assumption: Materials achieve second life in new building

value_proposition.residual_value: Higher end-of-life value due to recoverable materials
value_proposition.lifecycle_cost: Lower over 100 years due to material reuse

disassembly_manual.title: Disassembly Instruction Manual
disassembly_manual.purpose: Enables future contractors to recover materials

legal_framework.innovation: New contract forms (partnering) to share DfD risk
legal_framework.challenge: Material ownership and liability transfer at disassembly

key_insights: DfD achievable within social housing cost framework
6 standardized element types ensure future compatibility
RFID material passports create digital twin for recovery
Lime mortar critical for brick recovery
Mechanical connections require no specialist tools for disassembly
success_factors: Consortium approach (Circle House Lab) spread development risk
Multiple architect perspectives ensured robust methodology
Published disassembly instructions ensure knowledge transfer
challenges_encountered: Developing mechanical connections meeting structural codes while reversible
Creating legal frameworks for material ownership transfer
Insurance and liability for novel connection types
recommendations: Standardize element types early in design
Embed material passports during production (not retrofit)
Use lime mortar for all brick facades
Route all services through accessible shafts
Publish disassembly instructions for future owners

narrative.driver: Prove that Design for Disassembly can work within the strict cost framework of Danish social housing - demonstrating that designing for future reuse adds minimal cost while preserving material value for generations.
narrative.approach: Only 6 standardized precast element types. RFID material passports in every component. Mechanical connections throughout. Lime mortar for brick facades. Published disassembly instructions ensure future recovery regardless of ownership.
narrative.significance: Paradigm shift from using waste to eliminating future waste. First building designed from the start for materials to outlive the structure.
narrative.legacy: Circle House methodology being applied to subsequent Lejerbo projects. Disassembly manual serves as template for DfD documentation globally.
